dataset.title: Seed Storage Behavior and Germination of Fragrant Manjack (Cordia dichotoma G. Forst.) and Chinese Hackberry (Celtis sinensis Pers.)

abstract.para: The storage behavior and germination characteristics of seeds of the fragrant manjack (Cordia dichotoma G. Forst.) and Chinese hackberry (Celtis sinensis Pers.) were investigated. Freshly mature viable seeds of these 2 species could completely germinate under alternating temperatures of 30/20℃ with 8 h of light within 6 wk. The mean germination times of their freshly mature seeds were 15.6 and 11.8 d, respectively. Therefore, the seeds of these 2 species were shown to be nondormant. That is the reason why 4℃ chilling only had an effect on the rate of germination. The seeds of C. dichotoma deteriorated rapidly when the chilling period was extended to 9 mo and died completely after 12 mo of being chilled. With a stratification period extended to longer than 4 mo, seeds of C. sinensis forced seed germination under chilling conditions, and complete seed germination could be achieved when the chilling period was extended to 7 mo. Thus, 4℃ stratification is not an appropriate way to store the seeds of these 2 species for the short term. Seed germinability could be maintained at -20 and 4℃, for at least 24 mo at moisture contents of 4.5~12.7 and 3.8% (on a fresh-weight basis) for seeds of C. dichotoma and C. sinensis, respectively. This therefore confirms the orthodox seed storage behavior of these 2 species.

intellectualRights.para: Please contact JC Yang (yjc@tfri.gov.tw) to get usage agreement if you want to adopt these data in any presentation.

section.title: controll of seed moisture content
section.para: To obtain seeds at 4 and 3 MC levels between about 4%~20% of Cordia dichotoma and Celtis sinensis, clean seeds were divided into 4 and 3 sub-lots. Seeds of each sub-lot were desiccated at 2%~5% RHs in a hermetically sealed acrylic box containing a molecular sieve at 20 °C. A small fan was installed in the box to circulate the air. Immediately after the relative humidity treatment, each MC group was wrapped in an aluminium foil bag and stored at 5 °C for 3~5 d to allow the moisture to equilibrate within and among the seeds. The obtained MCs were 4.5 ± 0.2%, 8.9 ± 0.2%, 12.7 ± 0.3%, and 18.9 ± 0.9%; and 3.8 ± 0.8%, 9.6 ± 1.0%, and 19.9 ± 1.5% for Cordia dichotoma and Celtis sinensis, respectively.

section.title: storage treatment
section.para: The seed moisture of each MC group was determined, and seed bags were stored at three temperatures (-20, 4, and 15 °C) for up to 24 months. A factorial design was used to study the responses of Taiwan cow-tail fir seed survival to moisture content, temperature, and storage period. Thus, three temperatures (-20, 4, and 15 °C) were combined with 4 and 3 MCs (from 4.5% to 18.9% and from 3.8% to 19.9%), and with storage periods of 0, 1, 3, 6, 9, 12, 18, and 24; and 0, 1, 3, 6, 9, 12,15, 18, and 24 months for Cordia dichotoma and Celtis sinensis, respectively.

dataTable.entityName: Effects of storage temperatures and moisture contents on the germination percentage of seeds of Cordia dichotoma
dataTable.entityDescription: Effects of storage temperatures (-20, 4, and 15℃) and moisture contents (4MCs: 4.5%, 8.9 %, 12.7%, and 18.9%) on the germination percentage for 0~720 days of seeds of Cordia dichotoma.
